review.title: The NOESIS Network-Oriented Exploration, Simulation, and Induction System
review.abstract: Network data mining has become an important area of study due to the large number of problems it can be applied to. This paper presents NOESIS, an open source framework for network data mining that provides a large collection of network analysis techniques, including the analysis of network structural properties, community detection methods, link scoring, and link prediction, as well as network visualization algorithms. It also features a complete stand-alone graphical user interface that facilitates the use of all these techniques. The NOESIS framework has been designed using solid object-oriented design principles and structured parallel programming. As a lightweight library with minimal external dependencies and a permissive software license, NOESIS can be incorporated into other software projects. Released under a BSD license, it is available from

metadata.title: The NOESIS Network-Oriented Exploration, Simulation, and Induction System

sections.heading: The NOESIS Network-Oriented Exploration, Simulation, and Induction
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: System
sections.text: The paper introduces NOESIS, an open source framework for network data mining that offers a wide range of network analysis techniques, including network structure analysis, community detection methods, link scoring and link prediction, and network visualization algorithms, as well as a complete standalone graphical user interface that facilitates the application of all of these techniques. NOESIS is designed based on solid object-oriented design principles and structured parallel programming, and can be integrated into other software projects as a lightweight library with minimal external dependencies and a generous software license. Published under a BSD license, it is available at http: / / noesis.ikorg.

sections.heading: Contents
sections.text: I. Introduction 1II. The Design of the NOESIS Framework 2 A. System Architecture 2 B. Core Classes 2 C. Supported Data Formats 2 D. Graphical User Interface 3III. Network Analysis Tools 3 A. Network Models 3B. Structural Properties of Networks 4 C. Network Analysis Techniques 5IV. Network Analysis 6 A. Community Detection 6 B. Link Scoring and Prediction 8V. Abstract 11 Acknowledgments 11References 11; Electronic Address: victormg @ acm.org † Electronic Address: berzal @ acm.org Electronic Address: jc.cubero @ decsai.ugr.esI.

sections.heading: II. THE DESIGN OF THE NOESIS FRAMEWORK
sections.text: NOESIS is designed as an easily expandable framework, whose architecture forms the basis for the implementation of network data mining techniques. To achieve this, NOESIS is designed for abstract interfaces and a number of core classes that provide basic functionality, enabling the implementation of different features into independent components with strong cohesion and loose coupling. NOESIS components are designed to be maintainable and reusable.

sections.heading: A. System architecture
sections.text: The lowest component is the hardware abstraction layer (HAL), which provides support for executing algorithms in a parallel environment, concealing implementation details and much of the underlying technical complexity, and provides various building blocks for implementing well-researched parallel programming patterns, such as MapReduce (Dean and Ghemawat, 2008). For example, we would result = (duplicate) parallel.reduce (Index - > x [Index] * y [Index], ADD, 0, SIZE-1) to calculate the dot product of two vectors in parallel. HAL not only implements structured parallel programming patterns, but is also responsible for task scheduling and parallel execution. It allows for adjusting parallel execution parameters, including task scheduling algorithms. The reflective kernel is at the core of NOESIS and provides its most important properties (unified).

sections.heading: B. Core classes
sections.text: The core classes and interfaces shown in Figure 2 form the basis for implementing different types of networks with specific spatial and computational requirements. Basic network operations include adding and removing nodes, adding and removing nodes, or querying node neighborhoods. More complex operations are provided by specialized components. NOESIS supports networks with attributes both in their nodes and in their nodes. These attributes are defined using predefined data models, including categorical and numerical values.

sections.heading: C. Supported data formats
sections.text: NOESIS supports reading and writing network data sets using the most common data formats. For example, the GDF file format is a CSV-like format used by some software tools such as GUESS and Gephi. It supports attributes in both nodes and associations. Another file format supported is GML, which stands for Graph Modeling Language. GML is a hierarchical ASCII-based file format. GraphML is another hierarchical file format based on XML, the ubiquitous eXtensible Markup Language developed by W3C. Other file formats are supported by NOESIS, such as the Pajek file format, which resembles GDF, or the file format of the records of the Stanford Network Analysis Platform (SNAP) (Read kovec and Krevl, 2014).

sections.heading: D. Graphical user interface
sections.text: In order to allow users without programming knowledge to use most of the NOESIS functions, the standard NOESIS frame distribution comes with an easy-to-use graphical user interface. The NOESIS GUI allows non-technical end users to load, visualize and analyze their own network data sets using all the techniques provided with NOESIS. Some screenshots of this GUI are in Figure 3. A canvas is used to represent the network at any moment. The network can be manipulated by clicking or dragging nodes. At the top of the window, a menu provides access to various options and data mining algorithms. The Network menu allows loading a network from an external source and exporting the results using different file formats, as well as creating images of the current network visualization both as raster and vector graphic images. The View menu also allows customization of the network visual appearance by specifying the layout and binary attributes of the settings.

sections.heading: III. NETWORK ANALYSIS TOOLS
sections.text: NOESIS is designed to simplify the implementation of network analysis tools. It also includes reusable implementations of a wide range of popular network-related techniques, from graph visualization (Tamassia, 2013) and common graph algorithms to network structural properties (Newman, 2010) and network building models (Jackson, 2008). The network analysis tools included in NOESIS and the modules that implement them are presented in this section.

sections.heading: A. Network models
sections.text: NOESIS implements a number of popular random network generation models, which are described by probability distributions or random processes. Such models have proven useful for studying and understanding certain characteristics or behaviors observed in real networks. Among the models included in NOESIS, the Erdo-sRe-nyi model (Erdo-s and Re- ́ nyi, 1959) is one of the simplest. Gilbert's model (Gilbert, 1959) is similar, but a probability of existence is given instead for linkages. The anchored network model is also similar to the two previous models, with the advantage of reducing the occurrence of isolated nodes, but at the expense of being less than completely random. Finally, the linked random model is a variation of the anchored model that avoids isolated nodes. Other models included in NOESIS exhibit specific characteristics that are often found in real networks.

sections.heading: B. Structural properties of networks
sections.text: They can be used, for example, to measure the robustness of the network or to show important nodes and links. NOESIS considers three types of structural properties that can be calculated for nodes: for example, indegree and out-degree, indicate the number of incoming and outgoing links, respectively, the global properties. NOESIS offers a large number of techniques to measure the structural properties of the network that were included in the analysis: biased (Piraveenan et al., 2008) and unbiased (Piraveenan et al., 2010) Node-degree assortativity is a score between − 1 and 1 that measures the degree correlation between the pairs of connected nodes. Clustering coefficients can also be calculated for nodes.

sections.heading: FileReader fileReader =
sections.text: new FileReader ("karate.gml");

sections.heading: NetworkReader reader =
sections.text: new GMLNetworkReader (fileReader); Network network = reader.read (); PageRank task = new PageRank (network); NodeScore score = task.call (); Different structural properties for links can also be calculated by NOESIS. For example, the link difference, the number of shortest paths the connection is involved in, or the link rays, the number of possible paths between two nodes crossing a given connection, some of which are used by different network data mining algorithms.

sections.heading: C. Network visualization techniques
sections.text: The visualization of networks is a complex task, as networks tend to be huge, with thousands of nodes and links. NOESIS enables the visualization of networks by providing the functionality required to render the network and export the resulting visualization using different image file formats. NOESIS offers various automatic diagram layout techniques, such as the well-known Fruchterman pure gold (Fruchterman and pure gold, 1991) and Kamada-Kawai (Kamada and Kawai, 1989) force-based layout algorithms. Force-based layout algorithms detect forces between nodes and release the system to achieve an equilibrium point that normally leads to an aesthetic visualization. Hierarchical layouts (Tamassia, 2013) that arrange force-based layouts in layers that attempt to minimize edge crossings are also included.

sections.heading: IV. NETWORK DATA MINING TECHNIQUES
sections.text: Network data mining techniques exist for both unattended and monitored environments. NOESIS includes a wide range of community detection methods (Lancichinetti and Fortunato, 2009) and link prediction techniques (Liben-Nowell and Kleinberg, 2007), which are briefly described below.

sections.heading: A. Community detection
sections.text: There is a wide range of methods for detecting communities, their temporal complexity and their bibliographic references in the table I.NOESIS offers hierarchical cluster algorithms. Agglomerative hierarchical clustering treats each nodea as a cluster, and then iteratively clusters are merged until all nodes are in the same cluster group (Fortunato, 2010). Different strategies for selecting clusters for merging have been implemented, including single link (Sibson, 1973), which selects the two clusters with the smallest minimum distance; full linkage (Defays, 1977), which selects the two clusters with the smallest maximum distance.

sections.text: new FileReader ("mynetwork.net");

sections.heading: NetworkReader reader =
sections.text: new PajekNetworkReader (fileReader);

sections.heading: B. Link scoring and prediction
sections.text: Most linking techniques obtain this value by taking into account the overlap or relationship between the neighborhood of the nodes at both ends of the linkage. On the other hand, linking the linkage considers a value, weight or probability that corresponds to the probability of the existence of a particular linkage according to a specific model of linkage. NOESIS framework offers a large collection of methods for linking linkages and linkages, from local methods that only take into account the immediate neighborhood of nodes, to global methods that take into account the entire network topology. As the amount of information collected increases, the computational and spatial complexity of the techniques increases as well. Linking scoring and prediction methods available in NOESIS are listed in Table II. Among the local methods, the most basic technique is the common score (Newman, 2001), which is equal to the number of common neighbors between the two linkages.

sections.heading: Network network =
sections.text: new BarabasiAlbertNetwork (100, 1000);

sections.heading: LinkPredictionScore method =
sections.text: new ResourceAllocationScore (network); matrix result = method.call ();

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Currently, the NOESIS project comprises more than 35,000 lines of code organized into hundreds of classes and dozens of packages. NOESIS relies on a library of reusable components that, with more than 40,000 lines of Java code, provides an adaptable framework for collecting, supporting the execution of parallel algorithms, mathematical routines, and the model-driven application generator to build the graphical user interface of NOESIS. NOESIS facilitates the development of applications that analyze any type of data that can be presented as a network. NOESIS provides an efficient, scalable, and developer-friendly framework for data mining network data, which is released under a generous license for the Berkeley Software Distribution. Our framework can be downloaded from the official website at http: / / noesis.ikor.org.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The NOESIS project is partially supported by the Spanish Ministry of Economy and the European Regional Development Fund (FEDER) with a grant of TIN2012-36951 and the Spanish Ministry of Education under the programme "Ayudas para contratos predoctorales para la formacio ́ n de doctores 2013" (BES-2013-064699). We thank Aaro ́ n Rosas, Francisco-Javier Gijo'n and Julio-Omar Palacio for their contributions to the implementation of municipal verification methods in NOESIS.

referenceMentions.context: Data mining techniques are intended to extract information from large volumes of data (Tan et al., 2006).

Novel techniques have also been devised for semi-structured or structured data, since exploiting the relationships among instances from a dataset leads to new research and development opportunities (Getoor and Diehl, 2005).
For example, network data mining has been used to predict previously unknown protein interactions in protein-protein interaction networks (Mart́ınez et al., 2014).
It has also been used to study and predict future author collaborations and tendencies in co-authorship networks (Pavlov and Ichise, 2007).
Different network mining techniques are used by popular internet search engines to rank the most relevant websites (Page et al., 1999).

Some of them also include implementations of specific network data mining techniques, such as community detection algorithms or predictive models, including link prediction (Lü and Zhou, 2011) and epidemic models (Keeling and Eames, 2005).

Some of them also include implementations of specific network data mining techniques, such as community detection algorithms or predictive models, including link prediction (Lü and Zhou, 2011) and epidemic models (Keeling and Eames, 2005).
For instance, Pajek (Batagelj and Mrvar, 1998), NodeXL (Smith et al., 2009), Gephi (Bastian et al.

, 2002) and Cytoscape (Shannon et al., 2003) are two well–known alternatives for network visualization.
Finally, igraph (Csardi and Nepusz, 2006) and NetworkX (Schult and Swart, 2008) are two popular software libraries of network algorithms.
This component provides different building blocks for implementing well-studied parallel programming design patterns, such as MapReduce (Dean and Ghemawat, 2008).

Other file formats are supported by NOESIS, such as the Pajek file format, which is similar to GDF, or the file format of the datasets from the Stanford Network Analysis Platform (SNAP) (Leskovec and Krevl, 2014).

It also includes reusable implementations of a large collection of popular network–related techniques, from graph visualization (Tamassia, 2013) and common graph algorithms, to network structural properties (Newman, 2010) and network formation models (Jackson, 2008).

Among the models included in NOESIS, the ErdösRényi model (Erdős and Rényi, 1959) is one of the simplest ones.
The Gilbert model (Gilbert, 1959) is similar but a probability of existence is given for links instead.
For example, the Watts–Strogatz model (Watts and Strogatz, 1998) generates networks with small-world properties, that is, low diameter and high clustering.
Another model with very similar properties to Barabási–Albert’s model is the Price’s citation model (Newman, 2003).
been included: biased (Piraveenan et al., 2008) and unbiased (Piraveenan et al.
, 2008) and unbiased (Piraveenan et al., 2010) node degree assortativity.
The eccentricity of a node is defined as the maximum distance to any other node (Hage and Harary, 1995).
Decay is yet another reachability score, computed as the summation of a delta factor powered by the path length to any other node (Jackson, 2008).
Betweenness, also known as Freeman’s betweenness, is a score computed as the count of shortest paths the node is involved in (Freeman, 1977).
The most popular influence algorithm is PageRank (Page et al., 1999), since it is used by the Google search engine.
A similar algorithm is HITS (Kleinberg, 1999), which stands for hyperlink-induced topic search.
Katz centrality considers all possible paths, but penalizes long ones using a given damping factor (Katz, 1953).
Finally, diffusion centrality (Kang et al., 2012) is another influence algorithm based on Katz centrality.

NOESIS provides different automatic graph layout techniques, such as the well–known Fruchterman– Reingold (Fruchterman and Reingold, 1991) and Kamada–Kawai (Kamada and Kawai, 1989) force–based layout algorithms.

Hierarchical layouts (Tamassia, 2013), which arrange nodes in layers trying to minimize edge crossing, are also included.
Different radial layout algorithms are included as well (Wills, 1999).

Finally, the BigClam overlapping community detector is also available in NOESIS (Yang and Leskovec, 2013).
Among local methods, the most basic technique is the common neighbors score (Newman, 2001), which is equal to the number of shared neighbors between a pair of nodes.
For example, the Adamic–Adar score (Adamic and Adar, 2003) is the sum of one divided by the logarithm of the degree of each shared node.
The resource–allocation index (Zhou et al., 2009) follows the same expression, but directly considers the degree instead of the logarithm of the degree.

The adaptive degree penalization score (Mart́ınez et al., 2016) also follows the same approach, yet automatically determines an adequate degree penalization by considering properties of the network topology.

Random walk O(cvd) (Pearson, 1905)
Random walk with restart O(cvd) (Tong et al., 2006)
Flow propagation O(cvd) (Vanunu and Sharan, 2008)
Pseudoinverse Laplacian score O(v) (Fouss et al., 2007)
Average commute time score O(v) (Fouss et al., 2007)
For example, the Jaccard score (Jaccard, 1901) normalizes the number of shared neighbors by the total number of neighbors.
Similarly, the Salton score (Salton and McGill, 1986) also normalizes, this time using the square root of the product of both node degrees.
The Sorensen score (Sørensen, 1948) considers the double of the count of shared neighbors normalized by the sum of both neighbors size.
For example, the Katz score (Katz, 1953) sums the influence of all possible paths between two nodes, incrementally penalizing paths by their length according to a given damping factor.
Random walk techniques simulate a Markov chain of randomly-selected nodes (Pearson, 1905).
An interesting variant is the random walk with restart (Tong et al., 2006), which models the possibility of returning to the seed node with a given probability.
Flow propagation is another variant of random walk (Vanunu and Sharan, 2008), where the transition matrix is computed by performing both row and column normalization of the adjacency matrix.
The pseudoinverse Laplacian score (Fouss et al., 2007) is the inner product of the rows of the corresponding pair of nodes from the Laplacian matrix.

Other spectral technique is the average commute time (Fouss et al., 2007), which is defined as the average number of steps that a random walker starting from a particular node takes to reach another node for the first time and go back to the initial node.

7 Different link scoring techniques applied to Les Miserables coappearance network (Knuth, 2009): common neighbors (top left), preferential attachment score (top right), Sorensen score (bottom left), and Katz index (bottom right).

metadata.abstractText: Network data mining has become an important area of study due to the large number of problems it can be applied to. This paper presents NOESIS, an open source framework for network data mining that provides a large collection of network analysis techniques, including the analysis of network structural properties, community detection methods, link scoring, and link prediction, as well as network visualization algorithms. It also features a complete stand–alone graphical user interface that facilitates the use of all these techniques. The NOESIS framework has been designed using solid object–oriented design principles and structured parallel programming. As a lightweight library with minimal external dependencies and a permissive software license, NOESIS can be incorporated into other software projects. Released under a BSD license, it is available from http://noesis.ikor.org.
metadata.creator: LaTeX with hyperref package
